summary: retroviruses are characterized by a unique replication strategy involving conversion of the viral RNA genome into double-stranded DNA by the virus-encoded reverse transcriptase. retroviruses can have either simple or complex genomes and are classified into the Orthoretrovirinae subfamily, comprising the genera Alpharetrovirus, Betaretrovirus, Deltaretrovirus, Epsilonretrovirus, and Lentivirus. bats are known to harbor more than 60 distinct viruses, including representatives from the Rhabdoviridae, Orthomyxoviridae, Paramyxoviridae, Coronaviridae, Togaviridae, Flaviviridae, Reoviridae, Arenaviridae, Herpesviridae, and Filoviridae families. it is possible that bats may represent hosts for diverse gammaretroviruses. all products were purified and enriched by PCR to create the final cDNA library that was sequenced on the Illumina sequencing platform (GAII) the resulting raw reads were assembled into sequence contigs using the Bruijn graph and SOAPdenovo software (29) PCR was performed using exTaq DNA polymerase (TaKaRa) all PCR products were ligated into the pGEM-T Easy vector (Promega) and transformed into Escherichia coli for plasmid amplification and purification. the universal T7 (5′-TAA TAC GAC TCA CTA TAG GG-3′) and SP6 (5′-ATT TAG GTG ACA CTA TAG-3′) sequencing primer first round PCR used nested primers 5-race-4 (5′-CCT ACT GGC TTC CCC TCC ACA TAC G-3′) and UPM (nested universal primer mix) for second-round PCR, the 3-race-3 (5′-GTC AGG GTT AAC AGC CCC TAG CCT G-3′) and NUP (nested universal primer A) were used for the first round. gamma-Gag1-forward (5′-CCC ACC AAT TTG GCC/T AAG GTA A-3′;
